awd_titl_txt: Developing Simulations for Introductory Physics with Feedback from Learning Assistants
awd_abstract_narration:
Simulations are of great importance in teaching introductory physics. They illustrate things that are too small to see, happen too fast to see, or cover concepts that are not visible in everyday life. The use of simulations is one way to bring these ideas to life, allowing students to investigate and visualize physics concepts. This project will develop four new simulations for introductory mechanics and research their effectiveness for student learning. Some questions to be addressed will be to what extent do simulations help students learn and what are the features of a simulation that lead to more effective learning. There is already considerable existing simulation research, but most of this research was not done on mobile devices (where student ownership of the device becomes a major factor which this project will make possible). These simulations are likely to be immediately put into wide use by the physics community as there are few high quality javascript/HTML5 simulations. The simulations will be publicly available on ComPADRE.
 
A second research question focuses upon Learning Assistants (LAs): What role can Learning Assistants (LAs) play in the design, testing, and pedagogical implementation of simulations? LAs are trained undergraduates who return to a course they took to help deliver interactive pedagogy and help students learn. In this project, LAs will apply their expertise to provide feedback about improving the simulations. This is a novel aspect of the project, possibly leading to new use of LAs elsewhere in curriculum development. Other data-gathering methods include A/B testing, think-aloud interviews, and video analysis of students using the simulations during class, through which the project will investigate conditions that improve student learning.

por.por_cntn:
Laboratory and investigative instruction are integral parts of science classes as they allow students to engage with physical phenomena and deepen their knowledge of course content. Interactive lab simulations allow students to easily explore physical concepts, encourage self-guided exploration, and may be more accessible, inexpensive, and less time-consuming than hands-on labs during setup and tear-down.  This NSF IUSE study explored the development and use of computer simulations and supporting instructional materials for topics in mechanics in an undergraduate, introductory studio physics class. As a part of this research project, the role of Learning Assistants (LAs) was explored as part of the design and development team. LAs are talented undergraduate students who return to a course as part of the instructional team to help transform that course. 

This research project had four primary objectives focused on the development, study, and dissemination of instructional materials for topics in mechanics.

  1. The development of HTML5 simulations and accompanying written instructional materials for topics of energy conservation, momentum conservation, simple harmonic motion, and rotational dynamics. One of the primary goals of this development was for these simulations to closely mirror traditional and widely used examples for the investigation of these topics so that they could be studied in comparison to traditional instruction as well as widely disseminated to other institutions and physics educators. 

  2. Leveraging Learning Assistants (LAs) in the development process and implementation of simulations and instructional materials into the classroom. LAs were interviewed as they went through the worksheets, and their feedback during the interviews was used to improve the simulations and worksheets.

  3. Experimental research on student learning outcomes from written assessments comparing (a) simulations, (b) traditional instruction, and (c) a combination of simulations and traditional instruction for both laboratory and discussion activities. Our results have shown no significant difference in student learning outcomes on written assessments between these three modes of learning. 

  4. The dissemination of developed simulations, teaching materials, and research to other physics educators at both the undergraduate and secondary school levels. 

 

The intellectual merit of this project includes numerous article publications, conference presentations, and instructional workshops by the members and collaborators of this project.  A recent example is a paper published in the 2020 Physics Education Research Conference proceedings, which can be found here. Publications, simulation links, and instructional materials from our project can be found at https://physics.bu.edu/~duffy/VIPER/. 

 

The broader impacts of this project include the use of the developed simulations and teaching materials by many physics educators in the USA and around the world.  A benefit of their use and this dissemination is the low cost and easy access of these materials for a wide range of academic institutions.  As our research results have suggested, the use of these simulation-based activities are as effective in supporting student learning outcomes as traditional lab and discussion activities. Furthermore, the free access to these simulations and accompanying instructional materials may help instructors overcome inequity barriers such as equipment cost, instructional time and space required for physical laboratory equipment set-up, or curriculum development support for instructors in writing new instructional materials for their students.
